findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The transactions are initially disabled for all users excluding authorized addresses. The owner can enable the transactions for all users but will not be able to disable them again.

findings.title: RLF - Redundant Liquidity Feature
findings.description: The contract implements an auto-generated liquidity pool mechanism. The fees that are going to the liquidity pool are always zero. As a result, the entire liquidity pool mechanism is redundant.

findings.title: DDP - Decimal Division Precision
findings.description: Division of decimal (fixed point) numbers can result in rounding errors due to the way that division is implemented in Solidity.

findings.title: RSD - Redundant Swap Duplication
findings.description: The contract contains multiple swap methods that individually perform token swaps and transfer promotional amounts to specific addresses and features. This redundant duplication of code introduces unnecessary complexity and increases dramatically the gas consumption.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `marketingWallet` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but the variable `swapTokensAtAmount` can be set to a big number, triggering a huge token swap. The price of the token can be highly volatile, leading to significant price volatility for parties involved.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure their values cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can lead to decreased readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: Boolean equality is unnecessary when comparing two boolean values.

findings.title: L14 - Uninitialized Variables in Local Scope
findings.description: Using an uninitialized local variable can lead to unpredictable behavior and potentially cause errors in the contract.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be useful for optimizing code, but it can also be error-prone. It's important to carefully test and debug assembly code to ensure that it is correct and does not contain any errors.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
